biogHist.abstract: Swan Homes, in Middle Swan was created from a merger of two Anglican children's homes in 1943.The Perth Girls' Orphanage was evacuated to Swan Boys' Orphanage at Middle Swan during World War II, and the two children's homes merged into one institution. During this time, the type of accommodation changed from dormitories to large houses on the Middle Swan site. Swan Homes admitted children who were wards of the State, child migrants from Britain, and children placed privately by family or others. In 1960, Swan Homes became Swanleigh.

chronItem.event: Location - Swan Homes was located in Yule Avenue, Middle Swan

descriptiveNote.p: Girls' Friendly Society was actively involved with fundraising for Swan Homes.

descriptiveNote.p: The Archivist responsible for the records of Swan Homes, now held at Swanleigh has advised that: 'Most of the Swan Homes records were placed in the original kitchen for storage which is a cellar underneath Brown House. Unfortunately with the ever present damp and storage against external walls, these records were exposed to mould and so were disposed of without a list being created to detail what they were. As a result of this there are few records prior to 1960 remaining, with the exception of some student files from the 1950s.'

descriptiveNote.p: Children and young people from Swan Homes came to the Seaside House at Coogee for annual summer holidays, and from 1946 it was run as a branch of Swan Homes, with children permanently placed there.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Royal Commission appointed to Inquire into the Care and Reform of Youthful Delinquents, State of Western Australia (1943)

descriptiveNote.p: Swan Homes was inspected by members of the Royal Commission appointed to Inquire into the Care and Reform of Youthful Delinquents.
Padbury Boys' Farm School operated as a branch of Swan Homes.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Church of England Council for Empire (later Commonwealth, then Overseas) Settlement, Records (1925 - 1981)

descriptiveNote.p: The Church of England's records centre in London may contain records about people who were sent as child migrants to Swan Homes in Western Australia after World War Two.
The Children's Society sent child migrants from Britain to Swan Homes in Western Australia.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Investigation into the Administration of the Child Welfare Department of Western Australia by RH Hicks, State of Western Australia (1953)

descriptiveNote.p: The Investigation into the Administration of the Child Welfare Department of Western Australia by RH Hicks reviewed conditions at Swan Homes in 1953.
Ross Fact-Finding Mission [British child migration] was interested in the welfare of children at Swan Homes.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Anglican Homes Response to Moss Questionnaire

archref.unittitle: Anglican Homes Response to Moss Questionnaire
archref.abstract: 'Anglican Homes Response to Moss Questionnaire' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a letter from the Anglican Homes for Children, responding to questions about the Swan Homes, Midland.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia

archref.unittitle: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia
archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Minutes of conference of representatives of institutions accommodating migrant children

archref.unittitle: Minutes of conference of representatives of institutions accommodating migrant children
archref.abstract: Minutes of conference of representatives of institutions accommodating migrant children' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It gives insight into the process of migrating children to Australia from Britain, and the inspection of their welfare after they arrive.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Coogee Home [II]

archref.repository: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives
archref.abstract: 'Coogee Home [II]' is a digital copy of an item held in the Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives. Written on the back of the image are the words: 'Barbeque area at Coogee - note new wing - bathroom and laundry. 9/33. Holidays - Coogee.' From 1931 to 1959 the children from Swan Boys' Orphanage (to 1942) and Perth Girls' Orphanage (to 1942), and then the Swan Homes (from 1943) and Padbury Boys' Farm School (from 1946), came to Coogee for an annual summer holiday. From 1946, there were children living at the Home all year and in 1948 a new ablution block and laundry had been built, giving an approximate date for this image.
archref.note: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Coogee Home [I]

archref.repository: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives
archref.abstract: 'Coogee Home [I]' is a digital copy of an item held in the Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives. Written on the back of the image are the words: 'Our Seaside Home. Coogee. 9/42. Holidays - Coogee.' From 1931 to 1959 the children from Swan Boys' Orphanage (to 1942) and Perth Girls' Orphanage (to 1942), and then the Swan Homes (from 1943) and Padbury Boys' Farm School (from 1946), came to Coogee for an annual summer holiday. From 1946, there were children living at the Home all year.
archref.note: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II

archref.unittitle: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II
archref.abstract: This is a file held online by the National Archives of Australia. It has draft reports on the Australian institutions which took unaccompanied British child migrants after World War Two.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Swan Homes

archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It gives information about the pocket money for their voyage, supplied to child migrants coming from Britain to Swan Homes.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Health Examinations

archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a letter from the Child Welfare Department in Western Australia. The letter gives a brief summary of the types of health examinations that were planned to be undertaken in institutions receiving child migrants from Britain after World War Two. These institutions were the Anglican Homes (Swan Homes), the Methodist Home for Children, Fairbridge Farm School and the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association. An example of the letter sent to all institutions is included in this excerpt from the file.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report [Excerpt] - Pocket Money

archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a brief summary of the types and amount of pocket money which the Australian institutions reportedly gave to child migrants from Britain. These institutions were the Anglican Homes (Swan Homes), the Methodist Home for Children, Fairbridge Farm School and the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Case Histories

archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a letter from the Child Welfare Department in Western Australia. The letter gives a brief summary of the types of 'case history' information that was sent to the institutions receiving child migrants from Britain after World War Two. These institutions were the Anglican Homes (Swan Homes), the Methodist Home for Children, Fairbridge Farm School and the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The Noisy Mansions : the story of Swanleigh 1868-1971

archref.unittitle: The Noisy Mansions : the story of Swanleigh 1868-1971
archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of The Noisy Mansions, which is a history of the Western Australian Anglican orphanage which became Swan Homes and finally Swanleigh. The Noisy Mansions was written by A. Roy Peterkin, the long-standing Director of the Home.
archref.note: Perth Diocesan Trustees, Anglican Church of Australia.
